item.title: Just Cause Creator's Studio Liquid Swords Announces Layoffs
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/liquid-swords-layoffs-just-cause-creator

Liquid Swords, the studio founded by Just Cause franchise creator Christofer Sundberg, has announced a round of layoffs, making it the latest NetEase studio to be hit by funding cuts or downsizing efforts.

In a message on the official Liquid Swords website, the studio says the layoffs are part of "an effort to scale back operations and adapt to current business conditions", which is becoming an increasingly common refrain across the industry.

Liquid Swords goes on to say that the layoffs will go towards ensuring the studio's "long-term sustainability" as it continues to work on its debut title, so it sounds as though that game - whatever it may be - hasn't been canceled, at the very least.

Sundberg says that his mission with Liquid Swords is to "build a studio redefining game development with a small, expert-driven team and a sustainable business model", and that "shifting market conditions" forced him to "part ways with talented individuals".

Despite this, Sundberg says he and Liquid Swords remain "committed to [their] vision" for the debut game and that work on the project will continue.

The game has yet to be announced, but Liquid Swords says it's "confident that this extremely unfortunate setback will not prevent it from realizing its original ambition" for the title. Here's hoping that we get an announcement for it at some point in the future.

Liquid Swords was originally founded back in 2020. Helmed by Sundberg, the studio also includes alumni from franchises like Battlefield, Grand Theft Auto, and Payday.

Unfortunately, Liquid Swords isn't the only NetEase-funded studio to undergo downsizing or funding reduction in recent months.

Others include Worlds Untold, the studio founded by BioWare veteran Mac Walters, as well as Jar of Sparks, which is headed up by Halo veteran Jerry Hook.

It's not just NetEase studios, either; other smaller indie outfits are closing their doors or cancelling projects too, including the likes of Casey Hudson's Humanoid Origin and Dr. Disrespect's former studio Midnight Society, among many others.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 Sales Hit 2m in Under Two Weeks
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/kingdom-come-deliverance-2-sales-2m-two-weeks

Warhorse Studios has announced that Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 has hit another huge sales milestone, and the game hasn't even been on general release for two weeks yet.

In a post on X earlier today, the studio announced that its realistic medieval RPG has passed the two million sales mark, calling the achievement a "triumph" and thanking players who contributed to the game's sales.

Of course, Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 passing the two million mark probably won't come as a surprise to you if you've been following its progress. After all, the game passed a million sales on its launch day, and parent company Embracer Group announced sales were nearing two million just last week.

As a reminder, the original Kingdom Come: Deliverance took six years to pass the six million mark, eventually reaching eight million by November last year.

While there is, of course, no guarantee that the sequel will continue the momentum it's currently gathered, there's every chance that Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 will pass the six million point in a fraction of the time it took its predecessor to do so.

It looks like those wild rumors about the game's content, which director Daniel Vávra shot down prior to Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2's release, have done absolutely nothing to dull its edge when it comes to popularity.

Lest you worry that the RPG is slowing down now that it's finally out there in the wild, you can think again. Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 has a roadmap in place for the future, and it promises tons of new stuff for the game. Not only that, but official mod support via Steamworks is also on the way.

In case you're not up to speed, Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 is a medieval RPG created by Czech studio Warhorse.

Like its predecessor, the game eschews overt fantasy elements in favor of historical accuracy and realism. It takes place in early 15th-century Bohemia and sees protagonist Henry of Skalitz once again navigating a perilous world of political intrigue.

You can check out Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 right now on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S. Our Ashley gave the game a glowing review, praising its huge variety of activities and "outstanding" visual design.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Counter-Strike 2 Hits Highest Player Count Since 2023
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/counter-strike-2-player-count

Valve's first-person shooter Counter-Strike 2 has hit its highest player count since May 2023, and it isn't really clear why that's happened.

Counter-Strike 2 was surprise-released in September 2023, essentially serving as both a sequel to Counter-Strike: Global Offensive and a major update for that game as well. In May that year, when it was still Global Offensive, the game hit its all-time Steam player count high of 1,818,773 (per SteamDB).

This weekend, again according to SteamDB's numbers (with thanks to Dexerto), Counter-Strike 2 managed to hit a concurrent player count of 1,741,837, representing the game's highest player numbers since the Steam launch of both Global Offensive and Counter-Strike 2 itself.

It's worth noting that Counter-Strike 2's numbers (which were originally those of Global Offensive, lest we forget) have been trending upwards since 2012, and that the game has routinely been playing host to over a million players per day since 2022.

Still, there weren't any major CS2 esports tournaments over the weekend, and as far as I know, no major Counter-Strike 2 content creators have done anything particularly noteworthy over the past few days either.

It's entirely possible that Counter-Strike 2's numbers have simply hit this high as part of the aforementioned general trend upwards for the game, but it's still interesting (and no doubt encouraging for Valve, given how much the shooter rakes in) to see figures like this for the game.

Will Counter-Strike 2 manage to eclipse its all-time player high within the next few weeks? If the player count continues to rise, then it's pretty much an inevitability, which can only mean more skin sales for Valve. Hooray, I guess!

If you're still in the dark about Counter-Strike 2, it's a multiplayer first-person shooter that pits teams of terrorists against their counter-terrorist foes.

The game essentially plays the same as its predecessor; it's a reflex-based FPS with a focus on observation, quick thinking, and objective-based gameplay (unless you're playing in deathmatch, in which case it's a chaotic free-for-all).

When it made the switch to Counter-Strike 2, Valve's shooter got itself a new Source 2-based coat of paint, as well as new server architecture, updated maps, and more.

Counter-Strike 2 is available to play right now for free on PC via Steam.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Hunter x Hunter Nen x Impact Release Date Revealed for July
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/hunter-x-hunter-nen-x-impact-release-date

Bushiroad Games and Arc System Works have announced the release date for upcoming anime fighter Hunter x Hunter Nen x Impact, which will serve as the first major fighting game adaptation of the popular manga and anime.

As revealed during this weekend's Evo event, Hunter x Hunter Nen x Impact will launch on July 17th. When it does, you'll be able to play it on PC, PS5, and Switch. No release has been announced for Xbox.

Originally announced in December 2023, Hunter x Hunter Nen x Impact was originally scheduled for a 2024 release, but in September, it was delayed in order to allow the developers to add rollback netcode to the game.

If you're wondering what rollback netcode is, it's essentially tech that improves the quality of an online fighting game experience.

The long explanation is very technical, but in short, rollback netcode "rolls back" the state of the game if it detects a delay, but retains your own inputs, which makes online fights feel much more smooth.

Rollback netcode has been implemented in a number of hugely successful fighting games, including the likes of Dragon Ball FighterZ, Capcom's Street Fighter 6, and Bandai Namco's Tekken 8, as well as Nen x Impact publisher Arc System Works' own Guilty Gear Strive.

In short, while a delay to Hunter x Hunter Nen x Impact was unfortunate, it was put into effect so the developers could make it a more satisfying online experience, which it's hard to complain about.

Hunter x Hunter Nen x Impact is the first "full-fledged" fighting game to be based on the manga and anime series. It's a 3v3 battler in which you can play as a range of characters from the manga, including Gon, Hisoka, and Killua, among others.

You'll be able to check the game out when it launches on PC, PS5, and Nintendo Switch on July 17th.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
